Investment Strategy

Capitalizing on the Lithium Super-Cycle üîã

A detailed breakdown of our "Barbell" investment strategy, designed to optimize risk-adjusted returns in the generational electrification era.

Our High-Level Strategy & Rationale

The global lithium market presents a generational investment opportunity. Our thesis is anchored by a looming structural supply deficit, set to emerge in the latter half of this decade. This imbalance is the result of two powerful, secular demand drivers on an unavoidable collision course with a constrained and underfunded supply pipeline.

  • Relentless Demand Growth: The S-curve adoption of Electric Vehicles (EVs) and the exponential growth of grid-scale Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) are projected to more than double lithium demand by 2030.
  • Constrained Supply Pipeline: The recent market correction forced supply discipline, shuttered high-cost operations, and delayed capital-intensive projects. With mine development lead times of 5-25 years, the industry has failed to sanction the new supply critically needed to meet the coming demand surge.

This dynamic creates a high-probability scenario for a sustained recovery in lithium prices. Our strategy is designed to capitalize on this long-term trend by investing across the value chain in a structured, risk-managed way, targeting a 3- to 7-year investment horizon.

Timelines & Execution

Deployment (2025-2026): The current period of market rationalization offers a strategic entry point. We recommend deploying capital through the remainder of 2025 and into 2026 to build positions ahead of the widely anticipated market tightening and structural deficit, forecast to begin from 2027 onwards.

Drawdown (2029-2032): We will seek to draw down the portfolio as the super-cycle matures and valuations fully reflect the market deficit. This would align with the latter part of our investment horizon, likely triggered by clear evidence of a significant new supply wave being successfully financed and constructed, which would signal the beginning of the next cycle.

The "Barbell" Strategy: Balancing Stability & Growth

This strategy concentrates capital at the two ends of the risk spectrum to provide resilience while maximizing exposure to the coming supply deficit.

Core Holding

30-40% Allocation

A stable foundation of low-cost Tier 1 producers to generate cash flow, preserve capital, and provide resilience during market volatility.

Growth Engine üöÄ

40-50% Allocation

A concentrated selection of best-in-class developers offering the most significant leverage to a rising lithium price and key de-risking milestones.

Asymmetric Upside

10-20% Allocation

High-risk, high-reward innovators. Success is driven by technology breakthroughs and capturing strategic niches in the battery supply chain.

Prime Investment Candidates

A closer look at the curated selection of best-in-class assets and technologies that form our portfolio.

Prime Producer Pick

IGO Limited (ASX: IGO)

The highest-quality, lowest-risk exposure to upstream lithium production via its world-class Greenbushes mine.

Investment Thesis

A direct play on the world's largest, highest-grade, and lowest-cost hard-rock lithium mine. Its position on the cost curve ensures profitability even at the bottom of the price cycle, providing a resilient stream of earnings and dividends.

Core Producer

SQM (NYSE: SQM)

One of the world's largest and lowest-cost producers, extracting lithium from the rich brines of the Salar de Atacama in Chile.

Investment Thesis

Leveraging its bottom-tier cost position, SQM pursues a "volumes-over-value" strategy to grow market share. Its diversified business model provides a buffer against volatility, positioning it as a long-term consolidator that can win a war of attrition.

Prime Developer Pick

Standard Lithium (TSXV: SLI)

The most de-risked and institutionally validated Direct Lithium Extraction (DLE) developer in the world.

Investment Thesis

De-risked by a major partnership with energy supermajor Equinor, the use of Koch's proven DLE technology, and a strategic U.S. location that benefits from the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA).

Growth Engine

Vulcan Energy (ASX: VUL)

Pursuing a unique and strategically vital "Zero Carbon Lithium‚Ñ¢" project in Germany's Upper Rhine Valley.

Investment Thesis

Aims to produce battery-grade lithium from geothermal brines while generating renewable energy. This ESG-friendly model is strongly aligned with the EU's Critical Raw Materials Act and is strategically located to serve Europe's massive auto industry.

Asymmetric Upside

First Phosphate (CSE: PHOS)

A unique, strategic pure-play on the critical bottleneck in the North American LFP battery supply chain.

Investment Thesis

Vertically integrating its rare igneous phosphate resource in Quebec to produce high-purity phosphoric acid, directly addressing the goals of the IRA and Canadian industrial policy. Already validated with commercial-grade cells and offtake agreements.

Asymmetric Upside

Nano One Materials (TSX: NANO)

A compelling, capital-light investment in the future of battery manufacturing through a disruptive patented process.

Investment Thesis

Its patented "One-Pot" process for cathode active materials (CAM) is cheaper, cleaner, and more efficient. A licensing model avoids capex risk. Critically validated by a deep partnership with Tier 1 global supplier Sumitomo Metal Mining.

Predicted Performance Scenarios

Select a market scenario to view the projected year-on-year performance for each asset and the underlying assumptions.

The Bear Scenario: 15% Probability (A Tail Risk)

Assumptions: A severe global recession or a faster-than-expected breakthrough in alternative battery chemistries (e.g., sodium-ion) stunts EV and BESS demand growth. This demand shock, coupled with potential execution delays for developers, keeps lithium prices suppressed near the marginal cost of production for a prolonged period, delaying the structural deficit beyond the investment horizon.

Probability Rationale: This low probability reflects a 'black swan' event, such as a sudden, disruptive technology emerging or a severe, unexpected global economic depression that derails the entire energy transition narrative.

The Neutral Scenario: 55% Probability (The Base Case)

Assumptions: The market rebalances through 2026 as supply discipline holds. The anticipated structural deficit materializes from 2027 onwards, driving a steady, sustained recovery in lithium prices toward incentive levels ($15,000-$20,000/t). This environment allows high-quality producers to expand margins and well-funded developers to successfully de-risk and advance toward production.

Probability Rationale: Assigned the highest probability as it aligns with the majority of analyst forecasts, industry production schedules, and stated government policies. It represents the most orderly and predictable path for the market based on current data.

The Bull Scenario: 30% Probability (A Significant Possibility)

Assumptions: The structural deficit arrives sooner and is more acute than expected, driven by an exponential acceleration in EV/BESS adoption and significant supply-side disruptions. The market experiences a severe squeeze, pushing lithium prices well above incentive levels and leading to a rapid, substantial re-rating of all assets across the value chain.

Probability Rationale: This significant probability accounts for the historical tendency of commodity markets to overshoot during supply squeezes and the high potential for supply-side disappointments (e.g., project delays, geopolitical disruptions) which are common in the mining sector.

Navigating the Headwinds: Key Risks

While the long-term thesis is robust, investors must remain vigilant and actively manage a range of risks inherent to the mining and technology sectors.

Commodity Price Volatility

The lithium market has a history of extreme volatility. A sudden slowdown in EV sales or the faster-than-expected restart of idled capacity could lead to sharp price corrections. Our barbell strategy's core holdings provide a cash-flow buffer during these periods.

Project Execution & Technology Scaling

This is the most significant risk for developers. Projects can face delays and cost overruns. New technologies like DLE, while promising, have yet to be proven at a large commercial scale across diverse brine chemistries, presenting unique scaling risks.

Geopolitical & Regulatory Risk

Resource nationalism is a growing concern, with governments in key producing regions like Chile seeking greater state control. Our portfolio mitigates this by diversifying across stable jurisdictions like North America and Europe.

Technological Obsolescence

While unlikely in the medium term, research into alternative battery chemistries, such as sodium-ion, is ongoing. The emergence of a viable, high-performance, non-lithium battery could significantly impact long-term demand projections.
